most producers with this show would have taken the standard route and turned this into a melodrama over which of the two lawyers gets our main character. in this much smarter show, that has been taken off the table to pursue more and more interesting stories, in this episode we continue to see how a law firm struggles under a bankruptcy overhaul with nathan lane as trustee . this has truly comic moments such as when lawyers are forced to share offices. we also see all characters struggle with peter's mother Jackie without realizing that there is something seriously wrong with her. she is having hallucinations, seeing bugs where are none.  also her thought processes are getting jammed. she has always been so out of step with the present day world that they think it is just this same old problem with her.  then there is this week's court case which involves super inventive moves by opposing counsel which alicia and diane struggle to parry in court.  very, very smart law show and it shows that ridley scott, the famous and esteemed film director, is at the helm as producer.

Alicia is trying to win an internet lawsuit when Eli warns her that a reporter (the fabulous Miriam Shor) is about to print a story about Alicia and Will's affair. It turns out the story is about Peter and a campaign worker, and Alicia emotionally relives Peter's previous betrayals all over again. Kalinda continues her S&M relationship with her husband, while helping Eli determine if the campaign worker is telling the truth. And Rita Wilson is back as a lawyer trying to get Nathan Lane (as trustee) to intervene in Alicia and Will's case. A great episode with a great ending.

I thoroughly enjoy shows about today's modern courtrooms battles. It's win or lose for legal teams, fiefdoms for all powerful judges, and no one seeks justice. There is great drama and surprise twists in a system of law grown so large that if you were a speed reader and tried to read existing, new laws would be passed before you finished and/or old laws would be reinterpreted. Then you're got jurisdictional issues and all those government employees, bureaucrats, police, and foreign diplomatic immunity exempt from the law or protected by their brethren.

This is a fun show that leaps through different points of view. Enjoy.

Not just for Season 4, but from beginning to end: Terrifically intelligent and entertaining show on every level! Absolutely nothing--NOTHING!---stupid about it! I stopped watching "free" network TV ages ago because I thought the shows had become uniformly unwatchable. It turns out I was wrong. It's the perfect combination of episodic procedural, longer story arcs, and ripped-from-the-headlines issues, but with seriously fine character development. I have to add that Margulies' and Baranski's wardrobes are just luscious. I wanna look like them! She couldn't make up her mind; she allowed herself to do things that she didn't want to do; she drifted into affairs because she lacked self-control. Fox character was a refined white bread version of Lemond.

But Kalinda Sharma and the crazy lawyer were absolutely precious.  Kalinda is one of my favorite characters of all time.  If charm, innocence, sweetness, and vulnerability didn't work, then she used seduction.  If seduction didn't work or was inappropriate, she broke her targets knee caps.  My kind of woman.

And the crazy lawyer!  Crazy really is close to creative; it's a genetic thing.  And she had her crazy under control and her creativity was awesome.

But the main reason that I like this show so very, very much is the practice of the law, legal logic, the biases, how the justice system really works.  And they seemed to deliberately go after real world issues.  I loved it.  I learned.  I agreed with Alicia when she said that the law was neither good nor bad; it is neutral.  It is how we keep from killing each other.

I commented on another reviewer's statements regarding the unfortunate decision to take Kalinda's character down the wrong path. The addition of an abusive husband who has some type of sick hold over an otherwise strong character did nothing to enhance the mystery of Kalinda. In fact, it diminished her character. I don't think the writers really understood the strength of the character they had created. Whatever they intended her to be, Archie Panjabi took her beyond that scope and created a truly unique and memorable woman. It's no wonder Panjabi left the series after Josh Charles, and now, Julianna Margulies appears to be leaving as well. Even the Kings are leaving. In my opinion, the problems start with not fully appreciating the complexity of Kalenda's character. The decision to portray her as just another of Peter's conquests to damage her friendship with Alicia was the first of several miscalculations in developing the character of Kalinda Sharma. The writers took the easy way out with Kalinda and focused on superficial sexual encounters rather than providing more substantive character development. There are still many fine episodes in The Good Wife. But the heart has gone out of it.

Maybe I'm missing some, but they're not major and not enough to balance the sheer negativity of black characters in this show. Oh wait - there's Zach's black girlfriend - she's positive, but in a very small role.

Even when race is a major issue in an episode (I can remember only one), it's handled badly. In this last episode ("Je ne sais what?") He's booed, but Eli, his campaign manager, tells him that was his "Sister Souljah moment." Say what? That happened when Bill Clinton - once referred to as America's first black president because of his sympathy for the plight of African-Americans - denounced the lyrics of rapper Sister Souljah. Yeah, the non-racist white guy unafraid to tell blacks when they're wrong. But that's not what Peter was doing at all - which just shows me that the writers/producers don't know what they're talking about because they're just so...white.

Yes, it was created by two very white, pretty old people, but you'd think they'd get a clue. I mean, I'm as old and white as they are, but this aspect of the show is becoming very glaring to me. I like the show despite this failing, and I searched online for the criticism I'm making here but couldn't find any. Maybe it's just me, but I don't think so. In fact, I find this absence of criticism of the way black characters are portrayed even more curious. I'm watching the show differently since I started noticing this aspect of it in the second or third season, and so now when there are black characters, my antennae swivel toward the TV.

Alicia deals with the public humiliation by focusing on her newly ignited law career and her on-going affair with her homely Law Firm Boss/Sr. Partner/Ex-College Sweetheart, who she openly admits she doesn't love, while she definitely still loves her husband. "The Good Wife" is a masterful CBS legal and family drama. Season 4 continues its depiction of the travails and tribulations of a middle-age woman whose entire life was upended by the scandalous and criminal behavior of her husband, which had landed him in prison, and unable to care for his family. She is a law school graduate who has not practiced law for many years, after having given up her career to raise her children and manage the household. She re-entered the workforce as a junior associate at a prestigious law firm, and one of the name partners of her new firm is a former law school classmate, who had once been a very close friend. In this fourth season, the lead character continues in her role as a premier litigator for her financially-troubled law firm, and regularly takes on the most challenging and high-profile cases. "The Good Wife" is an interesting and compelling television program, which is characterized by superb writing, intelligent and thought-provoking story lines, and excellent plot and character development. The acting is first-rate, with stellar performances by the ensemble cast, which includes Julianna Margulies, Chris Noth, Christine Baranski, Josh Charles, Matt Czuchry, Zach Grenier, Archie Panjabi, Alan Cumming, Michael J. Fox, Carrie Preston, Makenzie Vega, and Graham Phillips, to name a few. I thoroughly enjoyed watching "The Good Wife," and I found it to be decidedly engaging and entertaining. "The Good Wife" is an outstanding television series, which truly merits a five-star rating, along with an enthusiastic recommendation.
